user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.2 is: A project shall not contain dead code.
Any operation that is executed but whose removal would not affect program behaviour constitutes dead code. Notes:
1. The behaviour of an embedded sytem is often determined not just by the nature of its actions, but also by the time at which they occur.
2. unreachable code is not dead code, as it cannot be executed.
3.Initialization is not the same as an assignment operation and is therfore not a candidate for dead code.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_CountSemTake_Impl:
```c
int32 OS_CountSemTake_Impl(const OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    OS_impl_countsem_internal_record_t *impl;

    impl = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_impl_count_sem_table, *token);

    if (sem_wait(&impl->id) < 0)
    {
        return OS_SEM_FAILURE;
    }

    return OS_SUCCESS;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function OS_CountSemTake_Impl:
#define OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(tbl, tok) (&tbl[OS_ObjectIndexFromToken(&(tok))])
...
OS_impl_countsem_internal_record_t OS_impl_count_sem_table[OS_MAX_COUNT_SEMAPHORES]
...
typedef struct
{
    sem_t id;
} OS_impl_countsem_internal_record_t
...
typedef struct OS_object_token OS_object_token_t
...
static inline osal_index_t OS_ObjectIndexFromToken(const OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    return token->obj_idx;
}
...
#define OS_SEM_FAILURE (-6)
...
#define OS_SUCCESS (0)
...
int32 OS_CountSemTake(osal_id_t sem_id)
{
    OS_object_token_t token;
    int32             return_code;

    /* Check Parameters */
    return_code = OS_ObjectIdGetById(OS_LOCK_MODE_NONE, LOCAL_OBJID_TYPE, sem_id, &token);
    if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        return_code = OS_CountSemTake_Impl(&token);
    }

    return return_code;
}
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
No code fragments in the provided functions appear to be dead code under MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.2. Rationale for not flagging any fragments:

- The local variable declaration and assignment (OS_impl_countsem_internal_record_t *impl; impl = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(...);) are used subsequently to obtain the semaphore id (&impl->id). Removing the assignment or the variable would change program behavior, so it is not dead code.
- The macro expansion OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(...) performs the table lookup needed to reference the semaphore record; this operation is used and affects behavior.
- The sem_wait(&impl->id) call is an executed system call that blocks or fails; its removal would clearly change behavior. The error branch (return OS_SEM_FAILURE) is reachable and affects return value semantics.
- The final return OS_SUCCESS is the normal successful return path; it is reachable and removing it would change behavior.
- The wrapper OS_CountSemTake performs parameter validation via OS_ObjectIdGetById and conditionally calls OS_CountSemTake_Impl; both operations affect control flow and return values, so they are not dead.
- There is no unreachable code in the presented snippets (no code after unconditional returns or impossible branches) and nothing that is merely an initialization mistaken for an assignment.

Given these points, there are no executed operations whose removal would not affect program behavior in the provided code, so no fragments are suspicious for MISRA Rule 2.2 violations.
